Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Situation2: They are approached by someone struggling with personal or family issues and need to provide consistent guidance and encouragement.
Story: I stared at my phone, rereading my sister’s message about the family holiday dinner. “We really want you there this year,” she wrote, her words heavy with hope. My family had always counted on me to be present, to laugh and share stories, to be a brother in every sense. But as I set the phone down, another message buzzed in—this time from Mark, a member of my congregation. His wife had just left him, and he was desperate for someone to talk to, someone to help him find his footing again. As a pastor, I knew my role was to offer support, to be available when my community needed me most. The dinner and Mark’s crisis overlapped, and I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. My family expected my presence, my laughter, my love. My congregation expected my guidance, my comfort, my time. I sat in the quiet, torn between the warmth of home and the call of duty, my heart aching as I tried to figure out how to be both brother and pastor when both needed me now.
